text: Interior: Jack Burden's Desk, Day Jack's fingers type out a story, the last line of which r "an honest man with courage." He pulls the sheet out and  hands it to Madison.
Here you are... the last of the Willie  Stark articles. Now can I go?
Yes. You've earned your vacation.  You've been writing these like you  really mean them.
Jack rises and walks toward the door.
I do.
Exterior: Ferry To Burden's Landing, Day Jack's car is ferried across the bay to the slip of Burde Landing.

(voice over) I hadn't been home in a long time.  Only a hundred and thirty miles from  Kanoma City. It was separated from  the mainland by a body of water. For  the first time I wondered if it wasn't  separated by more than that.
Exterior: Mrs. Burden's Home, Day As Jack arrives, Mrs. Burden and her husband, McEvoy, are seated at a lawn table near the boat landing.
Hello, Mother.
She runs forward to meet him.
Floyd, Jack's home. Oh, he looks  fine... doesn't he look fine? (to Jack, coquettishly) How do I look, Jackie boy?
You look beautiful, Mother.
I've got so many things planned for  you... parties and... it'll be just  like old times. But first, let's  have a drink.
Can't that wait until this evening?
She goes ahead and pours the drinks.
Floyd... honey... my son's home.
How long do you plan on staying?
(coldly) Two or three weeks. If that's all  right with you.
I'm sure your father would be --
Stepfather, Mother.
(reproachfully) Now, Jackie... here we all are. Floyd,  Jackie, myself. (raises her glass for  a toast) To the best time we've ever had  together.
Yes, Mother.
They drink. Mrs. Burden gulps hers down avidly. Jack look at her and then at McEvoy.
Excuse me... I...
He turns and walks back toward the shore. He boards a sma motorboat and heads toward a house that can be seen acros the water.

Exterior: Stanton Home (Burden's Landing), Day As the boat approaches the shore. Adam Stanton reaches do and pulls the boat up on land. He throws his arm around J and the two climb the hill toward Judge Stanton, who stan waiting to greet him.
Dr. Stanton, I presume.
(laughing) Is my shingle showing?
Good to see you, boy. Very good.
Good to see you, Judge. How have you  been? What have you been doing?
They walk back together to the patio tables.

Oh, just sitting here... waiting for  all of you to come home. You know,  when a man starts to get old his  eyes stray and play funny tricks on  him. As I watched you in that boat I  thought sure I saw a boy of twelve  with a fishing rod in his hands. And  I was sure the first thing he'd say  would be...
Jack catches sight of Anne Stanton walking down the path. runs to meet her. As they embrace, he looks back at the J
Do you mind if I kiss your niece,  sir?
He kisses her, and they turn and walk away.
Exterior: Tennis Court (Burden's Landing), Day Anne gracefully returns a ball to Jack, then runs to embr him at the net. Adam, seated near the court, smiles  approvingly.
Exterior: Gulf (Burden's Landing), Morning Jack and Judge Stanton in a rowboat, on their way to do s duck hunting.
Exterior: Gulf (Burden's Landing), Day Adam is at the wheel of his sailboat, with Jack and Anne  behind him.

Interior: Stanton Living Room (Burden's Landing), Night A party in the Stanton living room. Adam plays the piano. plays a waltz. Jack and Anne hold each other tightly as t move among the other couples.
Interior: Burden Dining Room, Night A formal dinner, attended by Jack and Anne, Mrs. Burden a McEvoy, Judge Stanton and Adam. Mrs. Burden is proposing toast.
To all the good times we've had  together at Burden's Landing. And  especially to this one. Because my  son's home.
Thank you, Mother. Thank you very  much.
Monty, Anne and I have been discussing  Jack's career. What do you think he  ought to go in for? Shall he be a  lawyer, doctor...
Jack looks at Anne.
We were just discussing whether you  should...
(to his mother) I like what I'm doing, Mother.
You do very well at it. I read your  articles about this fellow... Willie  Stark. Very convincing... Too  convincing for my tastes.
A lot of people like them.
A lot of people are fools. Articles  like that shouldn't be permitted.  They only tend to incite people.
What are you afraid of?

I thought they were very good. I was  proud of you, Jack. I was particularly  interested in Stark's ideas on health  and medicine. You know the conditions  at the hospital I work in. They're  intolerable. I'd like to meet this  Willie Stark. He sounds like an honest  man.
Honest man? This state is full of  these log-cabin Abe Lincolns with  price tags on them. The louder he  yells the higher his price.
You think you can buy anything, don't  you?
Yes, don't you?
There is a silence. Then McEvoy turns to the Judge.
What do you think, Judge?
I think this state could stand a few  changes.
(his face white) Well, I'll tell you what I think --
(quickly) Oh, please... let's not talk politics.
Anne is right. I absolutely forbid  any more of it. I know what we need,  we need another toast. (to the Judge) You propose it, Monty... you're so  good at it.
The Judge picks up his glass and stands up.
To the young people... to Anne, to  Jack, to Adam... To what lies before  them. To the world they'll make...  in spite of the mistakes we've made.

(rising) The mistakes you've made, not me.  You're all still pretty high and  mighty, aren't you? You all think  this state needs a change. You don't  like the way it's run. Well, who's  going to run it? Willie Stark? The  Judge? (to Jack) You? You can be bought too. As a  matter of fact you have been. And  with my money.
Jack's answer is to throw his liquor in his stepfather's  face. There is a pause. McEvoy wipes the liquor off with handkerchief.
(slowly) That's a waste of good liquor. (looks at Mrs. Burden) Your mother wouldn't approve.
Jack turns and leaves the room.
Jack...
She hurries after him. Exterior: Veranda, Night As Mrs. Burden comes out after Jack. Anne stands in the  doorway.
Jack... you go back in and apologize.
Apologize? I'd rather die.
I've got to live with him.
Well, I don't. Neither do you. You  don't love him, Mother. You never  did.
Son, don't spoil anything now... He  can help you.
I can get along without him. You  need this house. And the parties.  And the cars and the clothes and the  lies. I don't. It's the truth, Mother,  face it. For once in your life, face  it.
Mrs. Burden appeals to Anne.
Anne, please... please make him  understand.
Anne says nothing. Mrs. Burden goes back into the house.
Interior: Stanton Living Room, Night Anne and Jack sit alone in the room, beneath the portrait the old Governor Stanton.

Anne, Burden's Landing is a place on  the moon. It isn't real. It doesn't  exist. It's me pretending I live on  what I earn. It's my mother trying  to keep herself young, and drinking  herself old doing it. It's you and  Adam living in this house as though  your father were still alive. It's  an old man like the Judge dreaming  of the past... Anne, come away with  me.
And do what?
(rises impatiently) And live in a shack and eat red beans.  Anne, what do you want me to do?
Oh, Jack, Jack, you haven't been  sure. You've gone from one thing to  the other... a year at law school,  and now this job as a reporter...
Are you afraid I can't make a living?
Oh, no, Jack, it isn't that. I don't  care about the money. It... it's  just that I... I want you to be  something.
What is it you want me to be?
I don't know. It's just that I want  you to be... to do... something  important.
Jack looks up at the portrait of Governor Stanton.
Like your father. All right. I'll  run for governor. (pause) Anne, I'm sorry. I'm sorry I said  that.
All right, Jack. I'll go away with  you. I'll do anything you want me to  do.
They kiss.

Anne, I've wanted you to say that  more than anything in the world, and  now that you've said it... Anne, I  guess you were right. I'm not sure  of anything, including myself. I'm  not sure I could live up to the... (looks again at the  portrait) Anne, wait for me. Please wait for  me.
I'll wait for you.
Interior: Madison's Office, Day Madison is at his desk as Jack enters.
Hello, Jack. Cut your vacation short,  didn't you?
Yeah.
By the way, Jack, the fellow you  wrote the articles about... uh...  Stark.
Yeah?
He lost.
Well, I guess that's the end of Willie  Stark.
He turns around and walks off toward his desk.
Interior: Stark Farmhouse, Night Lucy and Willie are seated together at the table. Willie his law books open before him.
...Measure of the damages is caused  by...
(prompting) A breach...
A breach...
Of an agreement...
Of an agreement...
To sell personal property...
To sell... (slams the book shut) Oh, two years of this.
(leaning over to him) Oh, go on, Willie, go on.
He opens the book again.
Interior: Willie's Law Office (Kanoma City), Day Willie positions the framed diploma on the wall. The came pulls back to show Tom and Lucy, looking on.
Willie Stark... Bachelor of Law...
Exterior: Kanoma City Farm, Day Close shot of Willie, talking to a farmer.
If you'll just let me take your  case...
Exterior: Farm, Day Willie walks beside a farmer who is plowing his field.
Really, I'll wait for my fee. Just  as long as you want me to.
Interior: Willie's Law Office, Night Through the window, on which is printed "Willie Stark:  Attorney at Law," we see Willie, alone, pacing back and f in his office.
Go on, Willie, go on.
They're not going to kick me around  like I was dirt.
If you lose you can give a little  more time studying your law books.
I'm going to be on that same street  corner tomorrow, Mr. Duffy!
By all means. Free speech, free  country, Willie.
That brick factory is owned by a  brother-in-law of one of the  commissioners. The county  commissioners rejected the low bid  on the schoolhouse.
Willie crumples a piece of paper in his hand and tosses i against the window.
Exterior: Schoolhouse (Kanoma City), Day A plaque on the school wall reads KANOMA CITY GRAMMAR SCH Interior: Schoolroom, Day Teacher faces her class. The clanging of a fire bell is h
All right, children, this is a fire  drill.
The children rise and start to march out of the room in d file.
Remember now, walk quietly.

Exterior: Schoolhouse, Day The children's feet, as they climb down the fire escape.  Camera pans past children to an iron rod supporting the f escape. The brick around the rod starts to crumble and it rips loose. The children scream out in fear and agony.

Exterior: Cemetery, Day The whole town is there. Willie Stark, Lucy, Tom stand  modestly in the background. Quiet sobbing is heard as the minister reads from the Bible. When he finishes the praye he walks past the line of mourners, shaking their hands. ceremony is over. As they start to go, a man spots Willie goes over to him, and lifts Willie's arm in the air.
Oh, Lord, I'm punished for voting  against an honest man.
This sudden action brings response; women begin to cry an people push their way forward to grab Willie by the hand.
God bless you, Willie. If we had  only listened to you, Willie. You  were right, Willie. Let me shake  your hand, Willie. We should have  listened, Willie. You were right all  the time.
On Willie's face is the realization that something import has happened to him.

Interior: Stark Farmhouse, Night An article is pasted in a scrapbook. It reads: "VOICE IN WILDERNESS. Recent school tragedy is a potent reminder th a man named Willie Stark..." A hand draws a pencil undern the name.
A voice in the wilderness. A man  named Willie Stark...
Camera pulls back to show Willie at the table busy with h scrapbook. He looks up at Lucy.
How about that, Lucy, that's me.
She looks at him, unsmiling, and sits down to help him cl various articles from other papers.
Interior: Stark Farmhouse, Night A series of clippings are being pasted in the scrapbook.  They read:
"Will prove graft cause of tragedy," says Attorney Stark.
Draft Stark to lead fight to rid state of graft.

head_text.subj: C. CITIZENS COMMITTEE DEMANDS STATE-WIDE INVESTIGATION

text: D. Large photograph of Willie. Under it, the caption: RUR
Interior: Madison's Office, The Chronicle, Day The clippings are spread out on Madison's desk. He looks at Jack.
Get up there. Get up there fast.  Your friend, Willie, is hotter than  a firecracker.
Jack starts toward the door.
Stay there with him.
Interior: Harrison's Political Headquarters (State Capita Day A politician points to a map on the wall.
Look, before this Kanoma City business  we had this whole area tied up. Now  we're losing to Hickville.
Camera pulls back, revealing the candidate, Harrison, Tin Duffy, and a woman, Sadie Burke.
We must find a way to split that  vote.
Well, all I know is, the way it is  now it looks like I'm not going to  win.
I know a way... find a dummy.
Find a dummy. (looks at Harrison) That's what we've got.
A guy from the sticks... strong enough  to grab some votes and dumb enough  not to ask questions.
If you want to listen to a boy from  the sticks, I know just the guy.
They crowd around to listen.
Interior: Stark Farmhouse, Day Jack sits at the dinner table, with Willie and Lucy. Tom  stands next to Willie. Pappy dozes in his chair.
No more politics, eh, Willie?
No, I worked too hard in my time to  get there. I think I'll just go on  practicing law and make a little  more money.
The question I'd like to know is,  why all the speeches you're making  around the countryside?
Willie is about to answer when he hears the sound of  approaching cars.
Wonder who that is?
He goes to the window, and we see a big black limousine  turning into his drive. He opens the door and waits as Sa Duffy, Dolph Pillsbury, and other politicians climb the s to meet him.
Brought some people all the way up  from the state capital just to meet  you. (turns to others) Folks, I want you to meet Willie  Stark, the next governor of our state.
Willie, Lucy, and Tom beam happily. Jack looks skepticall at Sadie, whose only reaction is to smile, politely.

Exterior: Country Road, Day Close shot of three posters on a billboard. They read ELE JOE HARRISON (HAPPY JOE) GOVERNOR FOR GOVERNOR ELECT McMU WILLIE STARK FOR GOVERNOR. The camera pans to the road, where an old Model T comes  bouncing along. As it passes we see a poster stuck on its back: WILLIE STARK -- GOVERNOR. Exterior: Railroad Station, Day Willie Stark walks out on the platform at the rear of the train and talks to some of the townspeople who have gathe at the station.

Folks, if you'll just bear patiently  with me for a couple of minutes, I'd  like to tell you what this state  needs. It needs a balanced tax  program. Now I'd like to give you  the facts and the figures.
Some of the townspeople start to move away.
Interior: Train, Day As the train pulls away from the station, Willie turns ar to Jack.
How did it sound, Jack?
Fine, Willie, fine.
(alarmed) Say... I forgot to send a telegram  to Lucy... Conductor!
Jack and Sadie exchange looks.
Interior: Train Club Car, Day Willie, jacket off, works over a speech with Duffy as  Pillsbury and Sadie look on.
Now right here... right here I'd  like to add something about last  year's taxes... eh?
I wouldn't add a thing. Just give  them the facts.
Yeah... and the figures.
Great speech.
Sadie sips her drink.
Exterior: Street Corner (Upton), Day Willie stands on a platform, next to an American flag, re from his prepared speech.
What this state needs is a balanced  tax program. Last year, last year  the state claimed to have spent on  roads...

Sadie turns and walks away, no longer able to listen. Jac follows her toward the hotel. Interior: Hotel Lobby (Upton), Day As Jack and Sadie cross the street, enter the lobby, and down next to the front window. We can still see Willie an his small street-corner audience in the background.
Do you mind if I sit with you, Sadie?
(shrugs) Stand... sit...
Thanks... Tell me, what are you on  this merry-go-round for?
I take notes.
For whom?
For those who pay me.
Which is.
People.
Smart people.
Oh, yeah. Anybody that pays me is  smart.
You don't have to be smart to frame  a guy like Willie Stark.
No. No, brother, you don't.
(lights a cigarette) It is a frame, isn't it?
Why don't you give me a cigarette?
(gives her the pack) To split the vote and win the election  for Harrison, huh?
If you know, why do you ask?
I just want to make sure.
Yeah.
Look, why don't you tell the boys  back home to save their money. Willie  couldn't steal a vote from... from  Abe Lincoln in the Cradle of the  Confederacy.

I wish the poor... had enough sense  to have somebody give him a good  greasing for the beating he's going  to get. 'Cause this way all he gets  out of it is the ride. (looks at Willie  through the window) Hey, those speeches! Ain't they awful?  Ain't they just plain awful? Question  to you: if somebody told him he was  a sucker, do you think he'd quit?
Willie has just finished his speech and is on his way ove to the hotel.
I don't know, Sadie. I really don't  know.
(as he comes into the  lobby) Did it sound all right, Mr. Burden?
Fine, Willie, fine.
Thanks.
He and Jack go upstairs together. Sadie watches them.
Interior: Sadie's Hotel Room (Upton), Night Sadie lies on her bed, listening to Willie in the next ro rehearsing one of his speeches.
Now, friends, if you will bear  patiently with me for a few minutes,  I'll give you the figures. What we  need is a balanced tax program...
No, Willie, no.
Sadie pulls off a shoe and hurls it at the wall.
What I need is some sleep. Shut up!
Interior: Jack's Hotel Room (Upton), Same Time Willie lies on his bed. Jack finishes shaving in the bath as he continues to rehearse him.
(shouting back at  Sadie) Shut up yourself! (goes to bed, shakes  Willie) Listen, Willie, try it on your feet  this time.
Oh, no. Wait a minute. My feet are  killing me. Let me stay here, huh?
All right... Look, Willie, you tell  'em too much. Just tell 'em you're  going to soak the fat boys and forget  the rest of the tax stuff.
(pathetically) That's what I say.

But it's the way you say it. Willie,  make 'em cry. Make 'em laugh, make  'em mad, even mad at you. Stir 'em  up and they'll love it and come back  for more. But for heaven's sake don't  try and improve their minds.
(suddenly) A man don't have to be governor.
(surprised) What?
A man don't have to be governor.
Pause.
Well, they haven't counted up the  votes yet.

(quietly) Oh, I'm going to lose, Mr. Burden. I  know that. Don't try and fool me.  I'm not going to lie to you. I wanted  it. I wanted it so badly I stayed up  nights thinking about it. A man wants  something so badly he gets mixed up  in knowing what he wants. It's  something inside of you. I would  have made a good governor. Better  than those other fellows.
There is a knock on the door.
Come in.
(almost to himself) A great governor.
Sadie enters. She immediately spots the liquor, and pours herself a drink.
Since you won't let me sleep you  might at least give me a drink.
(muttering) Build them highways... greatest system  of highways in the country.
(to Sadie) Help yourself.
I'll build schools.
(to Jack) What's up?
Nothing... except Willie here has  been saying as how he's not going to  be governor.
(directly, to Jack) So you told him.
I don't tell anyone anything... I  just listen.
(goes to Willie) Who told you?
Told me what? Told me what?
That you're not going to be governor.
(getting up) Jack! Told me what?... Told me what?
Jack says nothing. Sadie gulps down her drink, bangs the  empty glass on the bureau top, and turns to face Willie.
(loudly) All right! That you've been framed,  you poor sap.
Willie looks at her steadily for a moment.
(quietly) Framed?

And how! Oh, you decoy, you woodenhead  decoy! And you let 'em. You let 'em  because you thought you were the  little lamb of God. But you know  what you are? (she waits for his  answer; he has none) Well, you're the goat! You are the  sacrificial goat! You are a sap...  because you let 'em.
Sadie! That's enough.

Enough? He didn't even get anything  out of it. Oh, they'd have paid you  to take a rap like that, but they  didn't have to pay a sap like you.  Oh, no, you were so full of yourself  and hot air, all you wanted was a  chance to stand up on your hind legs  and make a speech: my friends, what  this state needs is a good five-cent  cigar. What this state needs is a --
(to Jack) Is it true?
(prayerfully, to the  ceiling) He wants to know if it's true.
Is it true?
That's what they tell me.
There is a long pause. Willie looks almost as if he is go to cry. Sadie pours out another drink, a stiff one.
(handing it to him) Here.
Willie drinks it all.
Hey, lay off that. You're not used  to it.
(jeeringly) He's not used to a lot of things.  Are you, Willie?
(angrily) Why don't you lay off of him, Sadie?
(ignores Jack) Are you, Willie? Are you? Are you...  are you, are you, are you?
She shoves the bottle at him. He takes it and pours himse a drink.
Interior: Sadie's Hotel Room (Upton), Morning Willie is snoring on the bed. Sadie's coat is thrown over him. She is in the bathroom, applying lipstick. Jack ente
Hi.
Well, things seem to have quieted  down.
(laughs) Yeah, I quieted him down.
Yeah. How was he? Noisy?

Oh, he reared some. He's been telling  me all the things he's going to do.  He's going to do big things, this  fella. He's going to be President.  He's going to kill people with his  bare hands. I quieted him down...  Hey! Who's Lucy?
His wife.
He talks like she's his mammy...  she's going to blow his nose for  him.
Jack sits on the bed next to Willie.
Well, I'll take him from here on in.  They're waiting for him at the  barbecue.
Sadie pulls her coat off Willie and goes to the door.
Yeah, well give me a receipt for the  body and I'll be on my way.
She leaves. Jack bends over Willie, who continues to snor
Hey, Willie, Willie... come on, wake  up, Willie. Come on, Willie.
Exterior: Fairgrounds (Upton), Day A crowd mills about underneath a banner that reads HEAR W

Exterior: Fairgrounds, Day Willie, staggering a bit, hung over, reacts painfully to staggering height of the Ferris wheel. He leans on Jack f support, and they walk on. Exterior: Fairgrounds, Day Willie takes a seat on the children's swing as Jack goes to get some coffee. Two little girls stare curiously at h Willie waves them off. Jack returns with the coffee and p some whisky in it. Willie tips his hand, forcing him to p more, then gulps his drink down. Exterior: Bandstand (Upton), Day Duffy, Pillsbury, and the other politicians stand on the  platform, waiting for Willie. A band plays march music. D goes over to Sadie, who is standing on the steps of the  platform.
Where is he?
(pointing) There he is.
Escorted by Jack, Willie approaches the platform and stum up the steps past Sadie.
Whoops!
(to Jack) Is he drunk?
Never touches the stuff. Lucy doesn't  favor drinkin'.
Duffy follows Willie up on the platform.
(to Jack) How'd you get him here? He was out  stiff.
Hair of the dog that bit him.
Hair? He must have swallowed the  dog.
On the platform, Duffy looks uneasily at the bleary-eyed  Willie. The band suddenly plays a fanfare, and the chairm steps up to the microphone.
Ladies and gentlemen, it gives me a  great deal of pleasure to introduce  to you that true man of the people,  the next governor of the state...  Willie Stark.
There is scattered applause as Willie steps forward to sp
My friends...
He turns his face from side to side, and fumbles in the r side of his coat pocket to fish out his speech.
My friends... I...

He tries to focus on the speech, which he clutches before his eyes with both hands. Then he lifts his head, and loo directly at the people who have come to hear him. As he  speaks, the camera focuses on the faces of these people: farmers, workers, hicks, red-necks who are Willie's audie Willie's people.

I have a speech here. It's a speech  about what this state needs. There's  no need in my telling you what this  state needs. You are the state and  you know what you need... You over  there... look at your pants. Have  they got holes in the knees? Listen  to your stomach. Did you ever hear  it rumble from hunger?... And you,  what about your crops? Did they ever  rot in the field because the road  was so bad you couldn't get them to  market?... And you. What about your  kids? Are they growing up ignorant  as dirt, ignorant as you, 'cause  there's no school for them?... No,  I'm not going to read you any speech.
He throws his speech away. Duffy looks alarmed.
But I am going to tell you a story.  It's a funny story...
(from the steps) Hey!
...So get ready to laugh.
What's he up to?
Shut up!

Get ready to bust your sides laughing,  'cause it's sure a funny story. It's  about a hick... a hick like you, if  you please. Yeah, like you. He grew  up on the dirt roads and gully washes  of a farm. He knew what it was to  get up before dawn and get feed and  slop and milk before breakfast...  and then set out before sunup and  walk six miles to a one-room, slab- sided schoolhouse. Oh, this hick  knew what it was to be a hick, all  right. He figured if he was going to  get anything done, he had to do it  himself. So he sat up nights and  studied books. He studied law because  he thought he might be able to change  things some... for himself, and for  folks like him.
Sugar Boy listens intently, sharing in the anger in Willi speech.

No, I'm not going to lie to you. He  didn't start off thinking about the  hicks and all the wonderful things  he was going to do for them. No. No,  he started off thinking of number  one. But something came to him on  the way. How he could do nothing for  himself without the help of the  people. That's what came to him. And  it also came to him, with the powerful  force of God's own lightning, back  in his home country, when a  schoolhouse collapsed because it was  built of politics... rotten brick.  It killed and mangled a dozen kids.  But you know that story. The people  were his friends because he fought  that rotten brick. And some of the  politicians down in the city, they  knew that... So they rode up to his  house in a big, fine, shiny car and  said as how they wanted him to run  for governor...
Jack, electrified, grips Sadie's arm.
Sadie, he's wonderful... wonderful...
Duffy fidgets as Willie continues to pace and speak, his  face filled with conviction, and with fury.

...So they told the hick... and he  swallowed it. He looked in his heart  and he thought in all humility how  he'd like to try and change things.  He was just a country boy who thought  that even the plainest, poorest man  can be governor if his fellow citizens  find he's got the stuff for the job.  Well, those fellows in the striped  pants... they saw the hick and they  took him in.
He points his finger at Duffy, who is coming over to spea to him.
(low voice) Willie, what are you trying to do?
Willie turns on him, roaring.
There he is! There's your Judas  Iscariot. (he pushes Duffy across  the platform) Look at him... lickspittle... nose- wiper.
Duffy gestures frantically to the band.
Play! Play!
(pushing him again) Look at him!
Play anything.
The band starts to play, adding to the pandemonium. Willi shouts above it.
Look at him! Joe Harrison's dummy!  Look at him!
That's a lie!
Look at him!
Duffy signals to some of his goons standing near the plat
Go get him, boys... go get him.
Sugar Boy leaps up on the platform, his pistol drawn and  pointed at Duffy's men. Willie throws up his arms to sile the crowd.

Now, shut up! Shut up, all of you.  Now, listen to me, you hicks. Yeah,  you're hicks too, and they fooled  you a thousand times, just like they  fooled me. But this time I'm going  to fool somebody. I'm going to stay  in this race. I'm on my own and I'm  out for blood.
The camera moves in close on Willie's face.
Listen to me, you hicks...

Exterior: Willie's Speeches, Day and Night A series of close-ups of Willie's face as he shouts and j his message, always accompanied by the loud and frenzied  cheers of the crowd. Superimposed over his face is the fi of Jack Burden, at his desk, typing out his stories.
Listen to me and lift up your eyes  and look at God's blessed and  unflyblown truth... And this is the  truth. You're a hick. And nobody  ever helped a hick but a hick himself.
Loud cheers and yells.

All right, listen to me... listen to  me. I was the hick they were going  to use to split the hick vote. But  I'm standing right here now on my  hind legs... even a dog can learn to  do that. Are you standing on your  hind legs? Have you learned to do  that much yet? Here it is, here it  is, you hicks. Nail up anybody who  stands in your way! Nail up Joe  Harrison! Nail up McMurphy! And if  they don't deliver, give me a hammer  and I'll do it myself.
There is a photograph of Willie and a headline that reads

Superimposed over the newspaper is a shot of a crowd  applauding and yelling for Willie. Interior: Joe Harrison's Campaign Headquarters, Night Duffy, Pillsbury, and other aides stand looking at a post of Willie.
I want his throat cut, from ear to  ear.

Exterior: Willie's Campaign Montage Rock crashes through a window, knocking down a poster of  Willie. Poster being torn off the side of a building. A man is attacked as he tries to distribute leaflets.
Exterior: Jack Burden's Desk, The Chronicle, Night Jack is working on a story when Madison comes to his desk
No use going any further, Jack. We  aren't printing them any more.
I thought the Chronicle line was --
Divide and conquer? Stark is getting  too big for his britches and the  hicks are getting too smart. We're  now supporting Harrison.
(stands up) How do you square that?
I work here.
(putting on his coat) Well, I don't... not any more.
Jack, you fool.
If you had any guts you'd print  this...
I work here. I take orders.
I know. You've got a wife and three  kids and your boy goes to Princeton.
You won't find it easy to get another  job.
I'm too rich to work.
Exterior: Street Outside State Capitol, Day

Superimposed over newspaper is a crowd cheering at Harris victory parade. Willie, raincoat thrown over his shoulder looking grim, and Sadie and Sugar Boy are part of that cr They turn away and walk toward a bar. Interior: Bar, Day Jack is already at the bar. Willie, Sadie, and Sugar Boy  join him there.
We didn't do so good.
Double bourbon.
(sitting next to Jack) Same for me.
And a beer. (to Jack) I hear you got fired from the paper.
You heard wrong, Willie. I quit.
(passing the beer  back to Sugar Boy) You're smart. 'Cause before I'm  through with that mob they're not  going to have enough money left to  pay the boy that cleans the spittoons.
How do you feel, Willie?
I feel fine, fine. You see, Jack, I  learned something.
Willie and Sadie exchange looks.
Yeah... what?
Close shot of Willie.
How to win.
Exterior: Road, Day Jack stands on the side of the road, thumbing a ride.
(voice over) I didn't see Willie again until his  second campaign... four years later.
Interior: Office, Night Jack turns in some copy to a man at a desk.
(voice over) I drifted from job to job...
Exterior: Street, Day Jack and others in front of an employment agency.
(voice over) ...That is, whenever I could find  one.
Interior: Bar, Night Jack, at the bar, looking haggard and disheveled, picks u newspaper and turns to find a photograph of Anne. The cap reads STANTONS ARRIVE HOME.
(voice over) But always further and further away  from Anne, and the life at Burden's  Landing.
Exterior: Street, Day Camera pans with Jack as he trudges along the street.
(voice over) But Willie wasn't drifting. He knew  where he was going.
We see an insert of a newspaper. It has a caricature of  Willie, swinging a sledge hammer. The caption reads
(voice over) He had his foot in the door and he  kept right on pushing to get in. He  had lost the election but he had won  the state... and he knew it... and  the people knew it.
Writing on a fence: THE PEOPLE'S WILL SHOULD BE THE LAW O THE STATE... WILLIE STARK Painted on a rock: KNOWLEDGE BE
Lettering on a barn: FREE MEDICINE FOR ALL PEOPLE -- NOT

head_text.subj: A CHARITY BUT AS A RIGHT... WILLIE STARK

text: Poster on a building: MY STUDY IS THE HEART OF THE PEOPLE
(voice over) They were all hopping on his  bandwagon... even Tiny Duffy.

Newspaper caricature: it shows Willie on a bandwagon head for the state capitol. Everyone is trying to climb aboard Caption is THEY'RE ALL FOR WILLIE NOW. Huge poster on the side of a building: MY STUDY IS THE HEART OF THE PEOPLE.  Camera pans up to photograph of Willie on the poster.
(voice over) Yep, Willie came back like he said  he would.
Interior: Willie's Office, Day Willie is being interviewed by a group of reporters. Suga Boy lounges nearby, leaning against the wall.
Do you want to know what my platform  is? Here it is: I'm going to soak  the fat boys and I'm going to spread  it thin.

Exterior: Circus Grounds, Day We see balloons with inscriptions reading "I'm for Willie and a large banner stretching overhead, saying FREE CIRCU TODAY -- COMPLIMENTS OF WILLIE STARK. The crowd moves abo gazing at the clowns, animals, the trapeze act.
(voice over) Willie was right -- he'd learned how  to win...

Exterior: Park, Day A truck loaded with beer kegs pulls into the park. On the back of the truck is a sign: BIG STARK RALLY TODAY -- FRE BEER -- FREE FOOD -- EVERYBODY INVITED. Superimposed over this is the image of dollar bills floating through the ai
(voice over) He spent a lot of money doing it...  an awful lot of money... I was  beginning to wonder where he got it  from.

Montage: Willie's Second Campaign Hand holding check made payable to Willie Stark Campaign  Fund... $7000. Willie's hand reaches out and takes it. Hand holding check payable to cash for $5000. Superimpose is Willie, looking on, and his hand endorsing the back of the check. Another check to the Stark Campaign Fund for $3500. Poste of Willie is superimposed.
(voice over) There were rumors throughout the  state that Willie was making deals  with all kinds of people... strange  deals... for Willie Stark.
Crowd milling about circus grounds, with Willie's poster  superimposed. Fireworks exploding. Crowd cheers.
(voice over) The second time out, it wasn't a  campaign... it was a slaughter. It  was Saturday night in a mining town.
Huge poster is affixed to the side of a building. It bear Willie's face, and his slogans.
Exterior: Hotel (State Capital), Day Crowd stands about as Willie and Jack make their way into the hotel.
(voice over) He came back and he took me with  him.
Interior: Hotel Lobby, Day The lobby is packed as Willie, Jack, Sugar Boy, and Pills enter. Willie makes signals to Duffy to tag along with th entourage. Willie leans over to speak to the room clerk.
This is Jack Burden, a friend of  mine. From now on he's going to live  here. Give him anything he wants.
The group starts up the stairs, past the officers who are standing guard. Duffy stops to speak to one, pointing his finger at some of his men standing below.
Let these boys through, officer.
(to Jack) Duffy works for me now.
It looks like everybody works for  you.
They start up the second flight of stairs.
No. No, not yet. But I want to keep  him around. He reminds me of something  I never want to forget.
Willie stops and looks around at Duffy's men hurrying up steps.
(to Duffy) Come on, come on, come on, come on.  Are these the boys?
These are the boys that can get the  boys.
How many do you think we can get?
Fifty.
How much?
Five dollars a head.
(to Sugar Boy) What do you think, Sugar? Do they  look like good boys?
T-t-they b-b-better be.
Get a hundred... All right, go on,  all of you. Blow. Blow, blow. You  too, Duffy. Go on.
Duffy and his men turn and go downstairs.
(to Jack) Handbill distributors.
If they all look like them I'd hate  not to take one.
That's the object. Not like when  they beat up my boy Tom.
How is Tom?
Oh, he's fine. He starts college in  the fall.
Oh. And Lucy?
Willie's expression changes. He starts up the stairs.
Fine... fine.
Interior: Willie's Campaign Office In Hotel, Day The place is a beehive of activity, with typists and  messengers scurrying about, all supervised by Sadie.

Hey, I need a boy... Where's a boy? (boy runs up) Take that downstairs; they're waiting  for it. Right away, on the double. (to typist) Listen, baby, you've got to double- space all of this... he can't read,  see.
The door opens and Willie, Jack, and Sugar Boy come in.
Sadie!
(to typist) And they need four copies. (looks up) Hi, Jack. How are you?
Sadie is my secretary now. (to messenger, trying  to squeeze by) Oh, pardon me.
As Willie and Jack walk toward adjoining room, Sadie call out:
Fix your tie, Willie.
Interior: Bedroom Hotel Suite, Day Willie and Jack enter from the office.
Hey, Sugar.
Sugar Boy appears in the doorway. Sadie slips by into the room.
Keep everybody out of here. I want  to talk to Jack and Sadie alone.
He walks over to Jack, who leans back on the bed.
From now on you're working for me.
Doing what?
I don't know. Something will turn  up, won't it, Sadie?
Yeah. We need a college man around...  for research.
How much did they pay you on that  newspaper?
Three hundred dollars a month.
(laughs) I could buy you cheap, couldn't I?
For a bag of salt.
No. No, I don't play that way. I  like you, boy. I always have. I'll  tell you what I'll do. I'll give you  four hundred dollars a month and  traveling expenses.
You throw money around like it was  money.
Willie gets up and walks to the window.
Money?... I don't need money. People  give me things.
Why?
Because they believe in me.
Exterior: Burden's Landing, Day Willie's car is on the ferry crossing the bay to Burden's Landing. Sugar Boy drives the car off the ferry and up th road toward the house.
(voice over) I was going home again. But this  time it was different. Now I had a  feeling that maybe the waiting was  over... for me, and for Anne.
Interior: Stanton Living Room (Burden's Landing), Night Close shot of Willie standing in front of the fireplace,  beneath the portrait of Governor Stanton.
It's a far cry from where I come  from... to this house.

Camera pulls back. The room is crowded with people, all o them friends of the Stantons. Anne, Adam, Judge Stanton,  Mrs. Burden, and McEvoy are part of the audience sitting  around the fireplace. Jack stands next to Willie.
And standing here under the portrait  of one of the greatest governors of  this state, talking to you people...  well, it's an honor I never thought  I'd have.
Are there any questions? (looks around) Mr. McEvoy.
(smiles) No, I have no questions.
Judge?
A few... but it will hold.
I have a question.
Shoot.
A lot of people in this state have  been saying that you've been making  deals... some of them with the very  groups that you claim you're against.  Is that true?
Adam, you know how rumors start...
Yes. Yes, that's true. I have nothing  to hide. I'll make a deal with the  devil if it'll help me carry out my  program. But believe me, there are  no strings attached to those deals.
You're sure about that?

Doc, Jack here has been telling me  how you feel about things... how  you'd like to see a new hospital  built, a hospital that's the biggest  and best that money can buy. You  want those things, Doc, because,  well, because you're a man who wants  to do good. Now, I'd like to ask you  a question.
Shoot.
The guests laugh good-naturedly.
Do you know what good comes out of?
You tell me, Mr. Stark.
Out of bad... that's what good comes  out of. Because you can't make it  out of anything else. You didn't  know that, did you?
No, I didn't... There's another  question I'd like to ask you. You  say there's only bad to start with  and the good must come with the bad.  Who's to determine what's good and  what's bad?... You?
Why not?
How?
Why, that's easy. Just... just make  it up as you go along.
More laughter. Willie smiles and goes on.

Folks, there's a time to talk and  there's a time to act. I think the  time to act is right now. And with  your support, I not only will win  but I will do all of the things I  promised. I need your help. Oh, I  need it badly. But I'm not going to  beg for it. In the name of this state  which we love... in the name of the  governor in whose house we meet... I  demand it.
There is immediate applause. Anne is the first to rush ov and shake Willie's hand.
Exterior: Stanton Home, Night The last of the guests are leaving. Jack and Willie remai with the Judge, Anne, and Adam.
(to Judge) Well, what do you say, sir?
You've got to say yes. With you in  the race...
I'm an old bird... I...
But a game one.
They laugh.
Look, I'll give you complete power  as attorney general. You can do  anything you see fit. I'll swing the  ax to clear the way for you. Is that  a deal?
The Judge smiles, then puts out his hand.
It's a deal.
They shake hands.
Jack, we have to get back to town...  a lot to do. (shakes hands with  Adam) Dr. Stanton.
Jack kisses Anne on the cheek. Anne comes over and shakes Willie's hand.
I'm very glad to have met you.
Interior: Hotel Lobby (State Capital), Day People stand before the election return board in the hote lobby. Camera pulls back, revealing a newspaper picture o Willie, and the headline
Exterior: Street Outside Willie's Hotel Balcony, Night A crowd stands below Willie's hotel window, chanting toge
We want Willie! We want Willie!

A high angle from the balcony shows Anne, Jack, and Adam the center of the excited crowd, looking expectantly upwa Some of the people around them are carrying torches. Arc  lights play over the dome of the state capitol in the  background. In response to the chants, Willie appears on balcony. With him, standing on the balcony, are Tom and L The crowd erupts into cheers as he steps outside.
(raises his hands for  silence) This is not a time for speechmaking.  I should get on my knees and ask God  to give me strength to carry out  your will.
Loud cheers. Adam watches Anne. She applauds. Willie look down at the crowd and continues his speech.

This much I swear to you. These things  you shall have. I'm going to build a  hospital. The biggest that money can  buy... and it will belong to you.  That any man, woman, or child who is  sick or in pain can go through those  doors and know that everything will  be done for them that man can do. To  heal sickness. To ease pain. Free.  Not as a charity, but as a right.  And it is your right that every child  shall have a complete education.  That any man who produces anything  can take it to market without paying  toll. And no poor man's land or farm  can be taxed or taken away from him.  And it is the right of the people  that they will not be deprived of  hope...
The crowd applauds, and Willie waves. We see Anne, face a turn to Jack.
Does he mean it, Jack? Does he?
(as he walks away) That's his bribe.
Anne and Jack watch Adam as he leaves.

Montage: Willie Becomes Governor Willie, Sadie, and Jack leaving their old campaign  headquarters. Willie, Sadie, Jack, and others going upstairs in the  governor's mansion. The ousted politicians are just packi up and leaving.
(voice over) What if it was his bribe! He swept  the old gang out of office. What if  they hollered like stuck pigs? He  jammed through bill after bill and  the people got what they wanted.
Willie yelling at the legislators during a session.
I demand that this bill be passed.  Nobody's going to tell me how to run  this state.
Road excavation -- a bulldozer clears away dirt. A huge crane maneuvers over a dam site. Men are seen work on the girders of a large power plant.
(voice over) He started to build the roads, the  schools, the power dams, to change  the face of the state from one end  to the other... His methods?
Shots of uniformed policemen roughing up citizens. Willie and Sugar Boy move in on a man being held by cops. Willie looks on as Jack thumbs through his little black b

(voice over) Politics is a dirty game... and he  played it rough and dirty. Willie's  little black book was a record of  sin and corruption. And me, Jack  Burden? I kept the book and added up  the accounts.
Willie in a nightclub, surrounded by some show girls. A  photographer takes a picture of Willie with a girl balanc on his knee. Willie leads a marching band out onto a football field.
(voice over) Clown, show-off, playboy, they yelled  at him. Building football stadiums.  Fiercely proud of his son who played  in them.
Shot of Tom in football uniform running across the field  with the ball. Willie, in the stands, hugs Lucy.
Oh, look at him go. He's going to be  All-American.
Willie makes an inspection of the police. He stops to adj an officer's tie.
(voice over) They said he was building up a private  army. But he was building, always  building...
Sign at building excavation reads HERE ON THIS SITE WILL ERECTED THE GOVERNOR STARK HOSPITAL -- "TO HEAL SICKNESS.

head_text.subj: EASE PAIN. FREE. NOT AS A CHARITY

text: (voice over) Always playing up to the crowd.  Letting them trample on tradition.  Well, tradition needed trampling on.
A square dance at the governor's mansion. Willie dances w Anne.
(voice over) The crowd loved it... Willie loved  it... and so did I.

Interior: Executive Office Corridor, Day Jack walks down the corridor on the way to Willie's offic Interior: Willie's Executive Offices, Day As Jack enters from the corridor, Sadie is coming out of  Willie's private office.
(through open door) You low-down, no-good redneck...
She slams the door hard. We hear Willie laugh.
(to secretary) What goes on here?
That's what Sadie wants to know. (she shows Jack  newspaper containing  photograph of Willie  at the nightclub) The boss poses for too many pictures.
Jack grins, then walks into Sadie's office.
I'll kill him.
Why, Sadie, I'm surprised at you.
I'll kill him.
She goes to the door to yell to the secretary.
I hate all women.
She slams the door again, and returns to her desk.
Was she pretty?
Jack shoves the paper at her. She ignores it.
Was she pretty?
If I met her on the street I'd never  recognize her.
Was she pretty?
How should I know? I wasn't looking  at her face... Look, if it's going  to cause all this grief, why don't  you let him go?
Let him go? I'll kill him. I'll drive  him out of this state.
Just because a guy's sitting with a  couple of girls on his knees in  public...

Public or private... I know him. How  about what happened in Chicago? That  girl on skates... and the time you  both went to St. Louis... There's a  new invention, you know, Photography  and newsreels. Willie Stark in a  nightclub... Willie Stark with a  blonde.
You could always bleach your hair.
I could also break every bone in his  neck. After all I've done for him...  Now he goes two-timing me.
He's been two-timing Lucy. So there's  another kind of arithmetic for what  he's doing to you.
Lucy? (laughs) If she had her way he'd be back in  Kanoma City slopping the hogs right  now. And he knows it. He knows what  she'd do for him. She had her chance.
You seem to think Lucy's on her way  out, don't you?
He'll ditch her... Give him time.
You ought to know.
She slaps his face.
Hey, you got the wrong guy. I'm not  the hero of this piece.
The door to Willie's office bursts open and Willie dashes out.
All right, come on, both of you.  Let's go, hurry it up.
They go out through the reception room, pick up Sugar Boy and head down the corridor.
Come on. Pillsbury put his hand in  the pork barrel and got caught. You  know, I never did trust that guy.
Some newsmen are waiting on the top landing.
Have you heard about Pillsbury? What  do you intend to do about Pillsbury?  How about it, Governor?
Willie pushes by them.
Later, boys, later. (to Jack) Say, Jack, go back and get the Judge.  Let's get him over to my hotel just  as soon as you can.
They all hurry after Willie as he rushes down the stairs. Interior: Lobby State Capitol, Day Anne is about to go up the stairs when she meets Willie a the others on the way down.
(to Willie) I waited for you. (she sees Sadie) Hello. (back to Willie) You promised we could... uh... discuss  my charity project... Children's  home?
Well, I'm very sorry. Something very  important came up. You'll call me  later, won't you?
Yes, certainly.
We're late.
Anne watches as they cross the lobby and exit.
Interior: Stark's Hotel Suite, Night Close shot of Willie, seated, with his feet propped up on table. Pillsbury stands before him. Jack, Sadie, Duffy, a Sugar Boy are also in the room.

Look at you, Pillsbury. Fifty years  old, gut-sprung, teeth gone, never  had a dime. If the Almighty had  intended for you to be rich he'd  have taken care of that a long time  ago. The idea of you being rich...  that's plain blasphemy. Ain't that a  fact?
Pillsbury doesn't answer.
Answer me!
Yes.
Louder, man. Don't mumble. Speak up.  Say it's a fact, a blasphemous fact.
It's a fact, a blasphemous fact.
Sugar Boy laughs loudly. The phone rings and Sadie picks up.
Yeah?... Oh, I see. (hangs up) Dumond can't come. He says his wife  is sick.
I don't care if she's dying. Sugar,  get the car. Get him and bring him  over here.
Sugar Boy exists. Willie turns back to Pillsbury.

Now, you know what you're supposed  to do, don't you, Pillsbury? You're  supposed to stay poor and take orders.  Oh, there'll be some sweetening for  you from time to time... but Duffy'll  take care of that. Don't you go  setting yourself up on your own again,  do you understand that?
Yes.
Louder, man. And say, I understand  that.
I understand that.
Give him a pen and some paper, Sadie.
There is a knock on the door.
See who that is, Duffy.
Judge Stanton enters.

Oh, hello, Judge. Sit down. I'll be  with you in just a couple of seconds. (back to Pillsbury) Now write what I tell you to write...  Dear Governor Stark. I wish to resign  as auditor due to ill health, to  take effect as soon as you can relieve  me. Respectfully yours. (after a pause) Did you sign it?
No.
(roaring) Well, sign it! Don't put any date on  it. I can fill that in when I need  it.
Pillsbury signs the paper.
Now bring it to me.
Pillsbury moves slowly, so Sadie yanks the paper out of h hand and passes it to Willie.
Now get out.
Pillsbury slinks out of the room.
The papers have the story.
Yeah, I know.
They're talking about impeachment  proceedings.
(rising) Against who?
This time, Pillsbury.
I got that "this time," Judge.
How true is it?
It's too true.
The phone rings.
Yes? (hands phone to Willie) This is it, Willie. Jeff Hopkins on  the wire.
Willie takes the phone, but puts his hand over the mouthp so that he can speak to Jack.

What have we got on Hopkins, Jack? (as Jack riffles  through the black  book) Hello, Jeff. About that Pillsbury  business... (reads from black  book Jack holds out  for him) Here's what I want you to do when it  comes up in the legislature. Now,  wait a minute, wait a minute. You  listen to me. (still reading from  book) You got a mortgage coming due on  that place of yours in about five  weeks, haven't you? You'd like to  get it renewed, wouldn't you? (pause) All right, Tiny'll talk to you in  the morning.
He grins and hangs up the phone.
Get going, Tiny.
Duffy leaves.
You haven't answered my question.  Why are you saving Pillsbury's hide?

I'm not a bit interested in  Pillsbury's hide. It's something  much more important than that. If  the McMurphy boys get the notion  they can get away with this, there's  no telling where they'll stop.
(quietly) Or where you will... Pillsbury is  guilty. As attorney general of this  state, it's my job to prosecute.

Judge, you talk like Pillsbury was...  was human. He isn't. He's a thing.  You don't prosecute an adding machine  if the spring goes busted and makes  a mistake. You fix it. Well, I fixed  him. I'm not a bit interested in  Pillsbury. It's something much bigger  than that.
(getting up) Yes, it is.
He's right, Judge. Can't you see  that he's right?

He's right because you want him to  be right. Because you're afraid to  admit you've made a mistake. Do it  now before it's too late. (to Willie) I'm offering my resignation as  attorney general. You'll have it in  writing by messenger in the morning...  dated.
(softly) It took you a long time to make up  your mind, Judge. A long time. What  made you take such a long time?
I wasn't sure.
And now you are?
The Judge nods.

I'll tell you what you are. You're  scared. You sat in that big easy  chair of yours for thirty years and  played at being a judge. Then all of  a sudden I came along and put a bat  in your hand, and I said, go ahead,  Judge, start swinging. And you did.  And you had a wonderful time. But  now you're scared. You don't want to  get your hands dirty. You want to  pick up the marbles... but you don't  want to get your hands dirty. Look  at my whole program, Judge. How do  you think I put that across?
I knew how, but I never knew why.
He starts to leave.
You're not by any chance thinking of  going over to McMurphy's boys, are  you?
I'm through with politics.
I'm happy to hear that. (extends his hand) No hard feelings.
(ignores the hand) Goodbye, Governor. (to Jack) Are you coming with me, Jack?
Jack turns away.
You're making a mistake.
He goes. Willie closes the door behind him.
Do you think he means it when he  says he's through with politics,  Sadie?
No. No, I don't.
What about you, Jack?
I've known the Judge all my life.  He's always meant everything he's  said.
All right. All right. Take it easy.  I'll take your word for it.

Exterior: Willie's Hotel, Night Willie's car draws up to the curb. Sugar Boy hops out to  open the door for Willie. Sadie is watching him from a window upstairs in the hotel Anne is in the back seat; Willie leans down to talk to he
Sugar, take Miss Stanton home. (to Anne) When am I going to see you again?
She doesn't answer.
What's the matter, Anne?
Please take me home now, Sugar Boy.
You've got to understand me.
(turns away) I understand you. It's myself I don't  understand.
Do you think I like sneaking around  corners any more than you do? But  right now, with the Pillsbury business  and with your uncle quitting... If I  got a divorce...
Maybe we'd better stop seeing each  other.
No. No, we won't stop seeing each  other, will we?
(slowly) No.
Because you believe in what I tell  you.
(puts her hand on his) Because I believe what you tell me.
Sadie approaches.

Good evening, Governor Stark. (looks at Anne, but  talks to Willie) I thought you might like to know  that Judge Stanton kept his promise. (directly to Willie) He gave the story to every paper in  town.
Sugar, meet me at the hotel as soon  as you can.
Interior: State Legislature Assembly Room, Day Duffy stands in the forground, looking in on the uproar a confusion of the assembly.
These are serious charges that Judge  Stanton has given to the press. This  legislature is entitled to a complete  and full report on the Pillsbury  affair. Let the truth be known.
Let it come out.
I move that we adjourn.
I second the motion.
All those in favor, say aye... Motion  carried. The house is adjourned.
As Duffy turns and walks away, other senators rise up in  their seats in protest.

Sign on building reads: CITIZENS COMMITTEE MEETING, Subje PILLSBURY SCANDAL, 8 P.M. Tonight -- Town Hall. A man pastes a strip across the sign: CANCELED. A man is making a speech to a small group of people.
If you let Willie Stark get away  with the Pillsbury graft, there's no  telling...
Thugs break up the meeting. The speaker is beaten up. Jac Burden turns through the pages of the little black book.
Interior: Stark's Hotel Suite, Day Willie is lying on the bed. Jack is seated. Sadie and Sug Boy stand nearby.
But we beat the Pillsbury rap...  It's over.
These things are never over. I'll  tell you what I want you to do, Jack.  I want you to start a new page in  that black book of yours... under  then name of Judge Stanton.
You're crazy. There's nothing on the  Judge.
Why? Because his name is Stanton?
Ssshhh, easy.
What if I won't do it?
You know, some of this has rubbed  off on you.
What are you going to do? Have me  shot?
No... no... but I'll have to get  myself a new boy.
I tell you there's nothing on the  Judge.
Jack, there's something on everybody.  Man is conceived in sin and born in  corruption.
It's a waste of time.
What's the matter, Jack? Are you  afraid you might find something out?
Jack stares at him.
Exterior: Burden's Landing Ferry, Night Jack's car is seen coming across on the ferry.
(voice over) I kept saying to myself that Willie  was wrong about the Judge. If there  was anything left at Burden's Landing,  it was honor. I had to believe that.
Interior: Stanton Living Room, Night Jack and Anne stand together in the living room.
Anne, I want to ask you a question.  Was the Judge ever broke? Really  broke?
Why do you want to know?
I don't want to know, but I've got  to.
Did he tell you --
Did who tell me?
I don't know. I... how should I know  if the Judge was ever broke?
She walks away from him. Adam enters, carrying bundles of food and two wine bottles.
Hello... Come on, Anne, take this  food and start cooking. I'm hungry.
Anne takes the grocery bundles. Jack grabs the wine.
Me, I'm on the thirsty side. Bring  some glasses, Anne, quick.
He joins Adam, who has opened the piano.
(laughing) It's been a long time since I played  this thing. What do you say we wake  up the ghosts, huh?
(calling to Anne) Another glass, Anne, for a ghost.
(starting to play) Remember the last time I played this?  You and Anne were dancing?
Anne returns with three glasses. Jack grabs her around th waist and whirls her around.
Shall we dance?
Let's... let's have a drink first.
Adam starts to pour the wine.
No, no... keep playing. Anne and I  want to hear this, don't we, Anne? (Jack pours the wine) Adam... ghost... and me.
What shall we drink to?
To the ghost?... To Adam, to the  director of the new medical center.
(bangs the piano keys) Don't you ever stop working for him?
Adam!
I came up here to get away...
I'm sorry, Adam.
Well, I'm not. What's wrong with  being the director of the new medical  center?
Nothing, except that I'm not going  to take it.
Why? Because your uncle resigned?
That's partly it. There are other  things.
What other things?
(looks at her) You too?
Yes, me too.
Anne, if Adam doesn't want to discuss  it, let's not.
All right, let's discuss it.
But calmly.
Calmly. Go ahead, Jack. Why do you  think he wants me?
Because you're the best man for the  job.
It could have nothing to do with my  name being Stanton?
It could have. Let's grant that.
That's your answer.
No, it's not. If that were the only  answer I wouldn't be with him any  more. There's another side of it.  I've learned something from him. You  can't make an omelet without cracking  eggs.
Or heads.
But at least a hospital will be built,  and the sick will be cared for.
At what price?
At any price.
Do you really believe that, Jack?
I really believe that Stark wants to  do good. You do too. It's a matter  of method. Many times out of evil  comes good. Well, pain is an evil.  As a doctor you should know that.
Pain is an evil; it is not evil. It  is not evil in itself. Stark is evil.
The people of the state don't think  so.

How would they know? The first thing  he did was to take over the newspapers  and the radio stations. Why be so  afraid of criticism? If Stark is  interested in doing good, he should  also be interested in the truth. I  don't see how you can separate the  two. No, Stark is not for me.

(upset) No, Stark is not for you. Well, what  is for you? Pride. Pride, that's all  it is... foolish, stupid pride. All  you've ever talked about is what you  could do if... if somebody would  tear down and build. All right, all  right, somebody has, and he's given  it to you. But he's not for you. No,  he's not for you.
She throws down her glass and runs crying from the room.  Adam goes after her.
Anne... Anne...

Interior: Stanton Hallway and Stairs, Night Anne runs upstairs and Adam follows. The Judge comes out his room to see what has happened, sees Jack standing at foot of the stairs, hesitates a moment, and then goes bac to his room without speaking.
Interior: County Recorder Room, Day Jack enters and speaks to a clerk, who then directs him t one of the files. He starts to look through the files mar MORTGAGES DEFAULTED.

(voice over) Will I find anything, Judge? Will I?  I didn't find it all at once. It  takes a long time to go through old  courthouse records and musty deeds...  a very long time. But it wasn't too  hard for me. I was well trained in  research, especially this kind.
He pulls out a file.
(voice over) I found what I didn't want to find.
He takes the file back to the clerk.
Have some photostat copies made of  these. I'll be back tomorrow for  them.

Interior: Jack's Hotel Bedroom, Day Jack is lying on his bed, looking over the documents that relate to the Judge. He looks haggard and worried. There a knock on the door. Jack doesn't answer; the knock is  repeated.
Who is it?
It's me, Sadie Burke.
Wait a minute.
He hides the documents under his pillow.
All right, come in.
She comes in, sniffs the air.
Phew! Awful lot of smoke. Awful lot  of whisky. You sober?
Stone.
I'll have one with you. (starts tidying up  the room) What are you hiding out for?
I'm not. I've been sleeping.
For four days? You've been back in  town for four days.
Willie knows everything.
Willie's worried about his boy.
Willie's boy is worried about Willie's  boy.

Well, why don't you put something on  the phonograph -- a low-down, mean  blues. Play it over and over again  until you're sick of it. Then crack  it and go back to work. (sits down) I do it all the time.
That's not my problem.
No, it isn't your problem. (gets up again) I'll wait for you if you want to  powder your nose.
Jack goes into the bathroom.
I'll be with you in a minute.
Sadie wanders around. She goes to the dresser, upon which a photograph of Anne Stanton. She picks up the picture an places it so she can see it in the mirror and compare it  with her own reflection.

Hmmm. Yeah, I can see it. I've got  to look in the mirror to be able to  see it. Soft, white skin... not like  mine. (runs her hand across  her cheeks) I had smallpox when I was a kid.  Where I lived it seemed nearly all  the kids had smallpox...
Jack watches her through the open bathroom door.
It leaves your face hard. Then she's  got poise. Look at the way she holds  her head... at just the right angle.  That takes training. That takes years  of training...
Jack, towel in hand, comes out and stands behind her. He  looks at her in the mirror, puzzled.
I see what Willie sees. Willie's got  big ideas, Jack.
What do you mean?
A girl like that could be a governor's  wife. Or even a President's.
What are you talking about?
He ditched Lucy, he ditched me, and  he'll ditch you.
(shaking her) Answer me!
He'll ditch everybody in the whole  world because that's what Willie  wants. Nobody in the world but him.
What are you talking about?
You and your high-tone friends. What  do they know? What do they know about  anything? Why did you have to mix  her in?
You're crazy, Sadie. You're out of  your mind.
Am I? Well, why don't you go down  and ask her. Or ask him. Ask Willie.
Shut up!
Go ahead, ask him.
Shut up!
Ask him!
He slaps her hard.
Ow-oo... oh... oh.
She starts to laugh.
Exterior: Football Field, Day A football team is practicing on the field. Willie watche from the bench. A player kicks the ball and Tom misses it Jack walks over to Willie.
He's off today.
It's only practice. He'll be all  right tomorrow... You been gone a  long time, Jack.
Yeah. I figured if you needed me  you'd yell.
Why'd you lay around the hotel?
Thinking.
About what?
Things.
What did you find on the Judge?
Nothing.
You sure you didn't find anything on  the Judge?
Yeah, I'm sure.
You're going to keep trying, aren't  you?
If you want me to.
I want you to. There's something  else I want you to do too.
What? Bucket boy? Towel slinger?  What?
(looks at him closely) What's eating you, Jack?
(avoiding it) What else do you want me to do?
If you've got something on your mind,  boy, spit it out. We've been together  too long to play games.
What do you want me to do?
I hear your pal Adam Stanton turned  down the job as director of the  hospital. That's bad. Especially at  a time like this.
Oh? How did you hear it?
Why? What difference does it make?
I just wanted to know.
I heard it around.
(insistent) How did you hear he turned it down,  Willie?
Out on the field the boys have stopped playing and are hu around the coach.
I'll be right back, Jack. I want to  see what's happening here.
He goes over to the group on the field. The coach is talk to Tom.
You going to practice the way I tell  you.
I'm going to do it the way I want to  do it.
Willie comes up to them.
Tom, come here. What's going on here?
I don't care if he is your son,  Governor... No special rules for  him.
It doesn't make any difference to me  either way... whether I play or not.
Well, it does to me. (to coach) What do you want him to do?
To behave himself. Like the rest of  the boys. Four times this season  he's broken training. He comes on  the practice field half potted.
Tom, you're going to have to obey  the rules. Do you hear me? You're  going to obey the rules.

I put 'em across, don't I? Every  Saturday I put 'em across and I can  still do it, drunk or sober. That's  all you want, isn't it... for me to  put 'em across so you can big-shot  it around? Isn't that all you want?
He walks away.
Tom! (to coach) He's a little high-strung. (goes after Tom) Tom, come here. Tom!

Exterior: Highway, Foggy Day Sign in foreground reads: WILLIE STARK HIGHWAY U.S. 56. A car swerves around a bend and careens down the highway. Tom and his girl friend Helene are in the car. Tom is  drinking.
(laughing) Come on, Tommy... let's go faster.  Come on...

The car goes across a bridge, weaving. Two motorcycle cop parked there start to give chase. Tom's car swerves out of control and crashes through a fe The two motorcycle cops ride out to the field to the wrec car. They find Tom and Helene, unconscious. One of the co picks up the empty bottle and hands it to the other.
(looking at Tom) It's the governor's son.
He throws the bottle away.
Below the headline is a picture of Helene Hale's father.  Another picture of Mr. Hale on the front page. Caption re

head_text.subj: GIRL'S FATHER CLAIMS DRUNK DRIVING CAUSE OF WRECK

text: Interior: Governor's Mansion, Night Lucy and Mr. Hale walk across the large reception room to Willie. Jack, Sugar Boy, and Duffy stand around in the  background.
Willie, Mr. Hale's here to see you.
Willie comes to meet them, a drink in his hand. He is  obviously drunk.
Go on upstairs, Lucy. I have some  business I want to talk over with  Mr. Hale.
What I've got to say anybody can  listen to... Where's your boy?
Now... now, don't get excited. (to Sugar Boy) Get me another drink, Sugar.
My daughter may die.
She's not going to die. She'll get  the best medical attention there is.  No expense will be spared.
Where's your boy?
I'll get him.
Wait a minute, Lucy. He's asleep.  And the doctor said after a good  night's sleep he'll be all right.
No, he won't be all right unless you  make him all right. I'll get him.
She goes.
Lucy! (to Hale) You care for a drink?
No thanks.
Accidents will happen, you know.
Accidents? Your boy was drunk.
I saw the police report. There...  there was nothing about drunkenness  on the police report.
Whose police and whose report? I say  the boy was drunk. And I know it.
Tom comes down the stairs, with Lucy.
(to Tom) Right here before your father... I  want you --
Mr. Hale --
Tom, the doctor says you need rest,  boy.
(turns on him) I don't want you to try to cover up  for me. I was wrong... that's all  there is to it.
You don't know what you're talking  about. I saw the police report --
I don't care what the police report  says. I was driving and I was drunk.  It's all my fault. (to Hale) Anything you want to do to me, you  can do. Whatever you want me to do,  I'll do.
Nobody has to do anything. Stop  worrying. I'll take care of  everything.
I don't want you to take care of  anything.
Tom looks ill; he presses his hand to his forehead.
Tom, go on upstairs and get some  rest, boy. Go on... go on... go on.
Tom walks slowly toward the stairs.
Sugar, help him... Mr. Hale, come on  over and sit down. You sure you  wouldn't care for a drink, Mr. Hale?
Hale sits down, shakes his head.
Hey, Tiny, go home. Go on, out of  here... out of here. Go on.
Duffy leaves, disgruntled. Willie sits on a coffee table. pours himself another drink.
What business did you say you were  in?
I didn't say.
What business are you in?
Trucking business.

Trucking business. Trucks run on  state roads. If a man in the trucking  business had a contract with the  state, a big one, that would be pretty  good, wouldn't it? (to Jack) Go on, Jack. Tell him what would  happen.
Jack is silent.
Go on, tell him.
You're trying to bribe me, aren't  you?
No, no. No, I'm not trying to bribe  you. I'm... I'm only talking things  over with you, that's all.

You're pretty good at talking. I  remember when you first started  talking. A place called Upton. You  did a lot of talking then and the  things you said made sense, to me  and a lot of other people. I believed  in you... I followed you... and I  fought for you. Well, the words are  still good. But you're not. (rises) And I don't believe you ever were.
He walks out of the room.
(after a pause) Sugar, follow him. Keep calling in.
Sugar goes, leaving just Jack and Willie. Willie, very dr tries to get up but falls against the piano.
(yells) Lucy!... Lucy!
He staggers up the long stairway. Halfway up he tumbles,  groaning. Jack helps him to his feet.
I'd like Anne to see you now. I'd  like Anne to see you now, you drunken  sot! (drags him up the  stairs) Come on.
Photograph of Helene Hale on front page. Headline reads:
Under the photograph there is a caption:

head_text.subj: FATHER MYSTERIOUSLY DISAPPEARS AFTER BARING BRIBE OFFER B

text: Exterior: Governor's Mansion, Day Willie, Jack, and Sugar Boy are accosted by a group of ne as they come down the stairs.
What about the girl's father,  Governor? Have you a statement to  make?

All right, all right, gentlemen.  I'll give you a statement. This whole  thing is a mess of lies. It's a frame.  The man that made that statement...  have him repeat it to my face. He  can't. He vanished. Let me ask you  some questions. Where has he gone?  Where is he?
Maybe you could answer those questions  too, Governor.
Sugar Boy makes a move for the reporter but Willie holds back.
I won't dignify that question with  an answer.
One more question, Governor... Where's  your son?

At the football stadium, where he's  supposed to be. He's going to play  for State University, which this  administration is responsible for.  He's not hiding from anybody,  gentlemen. He'll be out there in  full view of seventy thousand cheering  fans. (starts down the stairs) One of which will be me. See you,  men.
He leaves, followed by Jack and Sugar Boy.
Exterior: Football Field, Day The game is in progress and the stands are packed. But th is no cheering. Instead we hear boos, and shouts for Tom.
Where's Stark? How about Tommy Stark?  Hey, Willie, send your boy in.
Exterior: Willie's Box Willie, Jack, Sugar Boy, and Lucy are in one box. Sadie a Duffy sit in the adjoining one. Willie is standing up. Th crowd continues to heckle him.
Why don't they put him in!
Come on, Willie... send your boy in.
A drunk comes over to his box.
What's the matter, Willie... is your  little boy ashamed to show his face?
Shut up!
Willie signals angrily to the police.
Get that man out of here! Come on,  get him out of here.
The man is dragged away. The crowd boos, and Willie gets and leaves the box, followed by Jack.
Interior: Stadium Dressing Room, Day Tom is sitting on one of the massage tables with a towel  around his shoulders as Willie and Jack come in. The soun of the boos can still be heard.
They're booing you.
(holds his head) Ever since the accident, my head...
The doctor said it was nothing.
Get dizzy... can't see... dizzy...
You're scared... plain scared.
(looks up angrily) Get out of here!
Atta boy... get mad. Show some spirit.  Jack, tell him what his playing means.  Go on, tell him.
You can never tell about a head  injury. Maybe the boy's hurt.

He's hurt? I'm hurt. It wasn't me  that wrapped that car around the  tree. It wasn't me that got drunk.  But me, I'm takin' the rap. (softer, to Tom) Go on, kid. Get out there and play.  Show 'em the kind of stuff a Stark  is made of.
(coldly) I wouldn't know.
Enraged, Willie slaps him. Tom fights back, and Jack has pull them apart.
Tom... cut it out!
(breathing heavily) All right, I'll play. Now get out of  here.
Camera holds on Tom as Jack and Willie leave. He picks up his uniform, stops, then rubs his head.
Exterior: Football Stadium, Day Tom is on the field. He runs up to the coach.
Stark's going in!

The boos turn to cheers. The crowd applauds. Willie signals from his box to the coach. He wants Tom se in. Tom runs out on the field and joins the team. The pla are lined up, in position to play. Tom shakes his head, a if trying to clear it.

Exterior: Football Stadium, Time Lapse The crowd yells excitedly. Tom, looking weary, gets the b and runs with it downfield. Three players tackle him hard and fall on him. A silence falls over the stadium as he f to get up with the others. In Willie's box, everyone is standing.
Tommy... Tommy... Tommy!
Willie rushes out onto the field and kneels beside Tom as the doctor and stretcher bearers arrive.
Interior: Hospital Waiting Room, Night Lucy and Willie are waiting for news about Tom. Sugar Boy comes in with a paper bag and sets it on a table.
B-b-boss, you gotta eat. You g-g- gotta.
Willie motions him away.
I'm the one that made him play. I  sent him in.
Sit down, Willie. Please sit down.
I sent him in.
What difference does that make now?
Jack comes in.
What goes on?
There isn't a plane flying.
They gotta fly. This is my son. He's  got to live.
Adam Stanton enters.
I just got a call from Dr. Birnham.  The earliest he can possibly get  here will be tomorrow morning.
Isn't there anybody else we can get?
I still think Dr. Stanton should  operate.
That's up to Governor Stark. He wanted  another doctor... a specialist. I  sent for one.
How bad is it really, doctor?
He's unconscious... and paralyzed.
Lucy slumps in her chair.
Has he got a chance?
To live? Yes.
What do you mean?
Even if the operation's successful --  that is, if he lives -- I think he'll  be paralyzed for life.

You'll do everything you can, won't  you? Anything between you and me..  that won't count, will it? It doesn't  have to. Look, doc, anything you  want in the world you just ask for  it and you got it. Go on, doc... ask  for it.
(coldly) There are some things, Governor Stark,  that even you can't buy. Do you want  me to operate, or don't you?
Yes... I want you to operate. (stands up) Please, may I see Tom now?
Yes.
They leave together.
(to Jack) How much does the doc know?
About what?
Oh, you know what I'm talking about.
About what?
About Anne and me.
(after a pause) He doesn't know a thing... not a  thing.
Jack turns and walks away.
Exterior: Hospital, Night Anne has been waiting outside the hospital. She turns to  Jack as he comes out the door.
Jack, how is he?
The boy?
Yes.
He'll live.
Oh, thank God. How is --
Willie?
He blames himself, doesn't he?
(as he walks down the  street) He'll find someone else to blame in  a few days.
(following him) Oh, I tried to call here at the  hospital, but I just...
They walk together, along the waterfront.
Anne... Anne, why did you do it?
He wasn't like anybody I ever knew  before.
You mean he wasn't like me.
He wasn't like anybody I ever knew  before. I love him, I guess. I guess  that's the reason.
Everybody loves him.
He wants to marry me.
Are you going to?
Not now. It would hurt him. A divorce  would hurt his career.
His career!
Jack... Jack, what are you going to  do? You can't leave him now. He needs  you now more than he ever did before.
What Willie needs, Willie's got.
You don't know him. You've known him  all these years and you don't really  know him at all.
What about Adam?
Adam?

Well, you don't have to worry about  him. If Adam finds out it'll be easy  to prove a Stanton is no different  than anybody else. (gives her the papers  on the Judge) Just show him these. Willie was  right... a man is conceived in sin  and born in corruption. Even Judge  Stanton. Show them to him, Anne.  Change the picture of the world that  Adam has in his head, just like our  picture of it has been changed.
He grips her by the shoulders.

Wipe out everything he's ever believed  in. It'll be good for him. There's  no God but Willie Stark. I'm his  prophet and you're his... (pushes her aside,  then feels sorry and  walks after her) Oh, Anne... Anne, I'm sorry. I didn't  mean... Anne!
A policeman comes over.
What's going on here?
Jack catches up to Anne. He takes her arm and they start walk back together.
It's all right, officer... we both  work for Willie Stark.
Exterior: Hospital Site, Day Willie, Anne, Adam, and Jack inspect a construction site. There are newsmen and photographers present.
(to Adam) Right over there, that's going to be  the main building... fifteen stories  high, like on the model. Over there,  that's the laboratory. Finest  technical equipment in the world.
What are you trying to convince me  of? I've taken the job.
Why?
My reasons are my own. Why are you  building a hospital?
To do some good for the people of  the state.
And get some votes.
Oh, there are lots of ways to get  votes.
Yes, I know... I won't stand for any  interference.
I won't interfere. I may fire you,  but I won't interfere.
If that's a threat, you're wasting  your time. You know what I think of  your administration.
Yes, I know. I'll tell you what...  You stay on your side of the fence;  I'll stay on mine. Is that a deal?
They climb up onto the platform, where the newsmen gather around to take pictures. Willie and Adam shake hands.
(voice over) Now he had us all... me, Anne, and  Adam. Now we all worked for him.
Interior: Projection Room, Day Willie, Jack, and Sugar Boy are watching a newsreel, simi in style to the March of Time newsreels. A producer, his  assistant, and two policemen are also in the room.

And so the eyes of the entire nation  are now focused upon Governor Willie  Stark, an amazing phenomenon on the  American political scene. The whole  state is filled with his  accomplishments -- each of them, of  course, bearing his personal  signature, to make sure that no one  will ever forget who gave them to  the state.
Large plaque on side of the highway: THIS BRIDGE WAS BUIL

head_text.subj: DURING THE FIRST ADMINISTRATION OF GOVERNOR STARK. A TOLL
BRIDGE STOOD HERE FOR FIFTY YEARS... NOW THE PEOPLE TRAVE

text: Camera pans to shot of the bridge. Plaque over college entrance: STARK COLLEGE... THAT EVERY

head_text.subj: MAN, WOMAN, OR CHILD, RICH OR POOR, SHALL HAVE AN EDUCATI

text: Shot of library -- lettering reads WILLIE STARK LIBRARY.  KNOWLEDGE BELONGS TO THE PEOPLE Shot of bad road running  through dry, barren land.
This is the way the roads used to  be. But there are those who claim  that they were adequate for the  people's needs, that you don't need  a four- or six-lane highway for a  horse and buggy.
Shot of horse pulling a plow. The empty, untraversed STARK HIGHWAY.

When Stark boasts of his great school  system, his critics say: you can't  go to school and work in the fields  at the same time. And they question  the benefit of these projects,  charging that the need and the poverty  of the people is as great as before.
Shot of large school. Camera cuts to men working in the f then to ramshackle barn, and to a farmer walking across h rotted cornfield.
Willie Stark has never forgotten the  source of his power: the people who  supported him.
Willie talking to the farmers.
He still keeps in touch with these  people of the backwoods, making  periodic trips to such places as  Kanoma City, now famous as his  birthplace...

Willie's official car and escort speeding through a stree Sign reads: KANOMA CITY, BIRTHPLACE OF WILLIE STARK Shot of Willie having his picture taken with Lucy and Pap on the porch of the old farm. Willie mending the fence on the farm. Willie feeding the  pigs.

For those who say that Willie Stark  is a man of destiny, there are others  who claim that he is a man of evil,  a man who cares neither for the people  nor the state, but only for his own  personal power and ambition.
Willie making a speech to a huge crowd of cheering people Willie inspecting his police force. Willie pounding the desk in the state legislature.
Obviously, these ambitions go far  beyond the boundaries of the state.  Just how far, only time will tell.  Meanwhile, he is here...
Big close-up of Willie as he delivers a speech.
...and from the looks of things, he  is here to stay. Willie Stark: messiah  or dictator?
The picture goes off and the lights in the room come on.
How do you like it, Governor?
Willie stands and faces the producer.
How many theaters will this play in?
All over the country.
Hear that, Jack. All over the country.
They start to leave. Willie stops for a moment.
Oh, there's one thing in there I  didn't like too well. That messiah  or dictator.
That's our point of view, Governor.  And that's the way it stands.
There is a silence. Willie's face is hard. Then he grins.
All right, all right, that's the way  it stands... as of now.

head_text.subj: STATEWIDE TOUR STARTS WITH VISIT TO KANOMA CITY

text: Tom and Pappy Stark are seated on the porch. Tom is in a  wheelchair. Lucy comes onto the porch as the sound of sir is heard, and Willie's two cars, motorcycle escort, and t car of reporters turn onto the drive. Tom, upset, flips h cigarette away as the cars stop in front of the porch. Lu puts her hand on his shoulder to calm him. Then Willie cl up the steps to greet Lucy.
Hello, Lucy... How are you making  it, Pa?... How are you, Tom?
Tom doesn't answer. Lucy offers her cheek to Willie. Sadi Jack, and Sugar Boy wait at the bottom of the steps, alon with the reporters.
I made some refreshments for your  friends. I'll get them.
I'll help.
(firmly) No, thank you. Thank you kindly.
If you don't mind, Mrs. Stark... the  boys have to get back to make the  morning editions. (to photographers) Set 'em up on the porch, fellows.  We'll take some pictures out here,  first.
He starts arranging the family for the picture.
Mrs. Stark, please... All right,  fellows, take one down there, will  you please... Shoot it up this way.
The cameras click.
Interior: Stark Farmhouse, Night Willie is finishing his meal, seated at the table with hi family and Jack. Sugar Boy stands behind Willie. Sadie ha left the table and is examining the room.

(on the last bite) You're still a great cook, Lucy.  Great cook. (gets up) Well, I guess I better be getting  back to town. Nice to have spent the  day with the family. (kisses Lucy on the  forehead) Goodbye, Lucy. (extends his hand to  Tom) Tom.
(ignores the gesture) Goodbye.
Take care of yourself, Pappy. Oh,  uh... how do you like the new radio  I got you? (walks over to it) You know how it works? You can get  police calls on it. Come here, come  here... I'll show you.
Pappy leans over as Willie demonstrates how it works.
This one for police calls up here.
He turns the dial.
Car sixty-two, proceed to five- eighteen Oak Street. Tom Jones beating  his wife again.
